title: Morgan L
text:
This is a Quarto website.
To learn more about Quarto websites visit https://quarto.org/docs/websites.
Hi! This is my project for DS002! I’m interested in minoring in Data Science! Outside of academics, I play rugby and like to bake with friends.

title: American Idol Seasons
text:
This dataset compiles the American idol winners and runner ups of the first 18 seasons, as well as release date, judges’ names, finals venue, number of episodes of the season, and original network and host. This plot compares judges’ appearance across all seasons.









The American Idol dataset I worked with comes from the TidyTuesday database.
[link] https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/blob/main/data/2024/2024-07-23/readme.md
The original dataset comes from Wikipedia.

title: Cetacean species
text:
This dataset compiles all Cetacean species and their birth information: their birth year, sex, location, mother, father, status, etc. This plot shows the total births per year by species.









The Cetacean dataset I worked with comes from the TidyTuesday database.
The original data set was made by Amber Thomas in her article for The Pudding.
[link] TidyTuesday (2018-12-18)
Thomas, Amber, Cetacean Insights: What We’ve Learned From Whales and Dolphins in Captivity. The Pudding 2017. https://pudding.cool/2017/07/cetaceans/

title: Netflix text analysis
Diabetes simulation study
text:
Code
library(tidyverse)
library(readr)
global_mortality <- read_csv("global_mortality.csv")
view(global_mortality)


This dataset presents the mortality rate for different diseases, per year (from 1990 to 2016) and per country. We are exploring the specific average rate of mortality from diabetes in the United States and in France across all years.
https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/tree/main/data/2018/2018-04-16
The original data comes from an article entitled Causes of death and published in the Our World in Data magazine by Saloni Dattani, Fiona Spooner, Hannah Ritchie and Max Roser at the following link:
Dattani, S., Spooner, F., Ritchie, H., & Roser, M. (2023). Causes of Death. Our World in Data. https://ourworldindata.org/causes-of-death
In this simulation study, we will explore whether France and the United States have the same average diabetes mortality rate. We will first calculate the observed difference in mean diabetes mortality between the two countries across all available years (1990-2016). To test whether the difference we observe could have been a result of random distribution, we will run a permutation test shuffling the diabetes mortality percentage rates countries 1000 times, to create a null distribution.
My research question is the following: do the United States and France have different mortality rates for diabetes on average from 1990 to 2006?
The null hypothesis (Ho) is that France and the US have the same average mortality rates for diabetes from 1990-2016.
The alternative hypothesis (Ha) is that France and the US have different average mortality rates for diabetes from 1990-2016.


Code
library(dplyr)

mortality_filtered <- global_mortality |>
  filter(country %in% c("France", "United States")) |>
  select(country, year, `Diabetes (%)`)


mortality_filtered <- mortality_filtered |>
  rename(diabetes_pct = `Diabetes (%)`)




Code
library(dplyr)
library(ggplot2)
library(readr)

library(dplyr)

mortality_avg <- mortality_filtered |>
  group_by(country) |>
  summarize(avg_diabetes = mean(`diabetes_pct`))

mortality_avg


# A tibble: 2 × 2
  country       avg_diabetes
  <chr>                <dbl>
1 France                4.72
2 United States         6.49


Code
ggplot(mortality_avg, aes(x = country, y = avg_diabetes, fill = country)) +
  geom_col(show.legend = FALSE) +
  labs(title = "Average Diabetes Mortality (%) Across All Years",
       x = "Country",
       y = "Average Diabetes Mortality (%)") +
  theme_minimal()









We observe a difference in average mortality rate between the two countries, so now we are going to test if this is a result of the random distribution model, by establishing a null distribution. Instead of comparing only the two countries’ averages, we will repeatedly shuffle the yearly diabetes mortality percentages between the two countries, recompute the average mortality for each country, and record the difference. By repeating this process 1000 times, we can see how large the difference would be between the two countries if we were following the random chance model.


Code
library(purrr)

obs_diff <- diff(mortality_avg$avg_diabetes)
obs_diff


[1] 1.773729


Code
perm_data <- function(rep, data) {
  data |>
    select(country, `diabetes_pct`) |>
    mutate(diabetes_perm = sample(`diabetes_pct`, replace = FALSE)) |>
    group_by(country) |>
    summarize(
      perm_ave = mean(diabetes_perm)
    ) |>
    summarize(
      perm_diff = diff(perm_ave),
      rep = rep
    )
}

set.seed(47)
perm_stats <- map(1:1000, perm_data, data = mortality_filtered) |>
  list_rbind()




Code
library(ggplot2)

ggplot(perm_stats, aes(x = perm_diff)) +
  geom_histogram(aes(y = ..density..), bins = 30, fill = "pink", color = "black", alpha = 0.5) +
  geom_vline(aes(xintercept = obs_diff), color = "red", linetype = "dashed", size = 1.2) +
  labs(title = "Null Distribution of Difference in Diabetes Mortality (%)",
       subtitle = "France vs United States (All Years)",
       x = "Difference in Mean Mortality (France - U.S.)",
       y = "Density") +
  theme_minimal()









p-value = 0 (< 0.05) so this is strong evidence to reject our null hypothesis.
We can reject the hypothesis that the mortality rates are the same for diabetes across all years (1990-2016).
There is strong evidence that the alternative hypothesis stating that France and the US have different average mortality rates for diabetes from 1990-2016 is true.
